first commit

* core/callcc.c: a start on call/cc. uses some inline asm to scan the stack frames and copy everything into a closure. this is very sketchy, it targets 64-bit with debug flags off and, while it's jumping right, it's not yet restoring the stack properly. a register must be missing or something.

Grouping details about op codes in compile.c

Previously there were two arrays statically initalized to hold the list
of op code names, and the op code arg counts. This patch makes a single
array of a struct which holds both the name and the arg count.

Hopefully this change will make it easier to add op codes; less counting
of values in the array to find the right spot to add the op arg count.

Trigger test failures by creating two new strings

The simple act of adding two new strings causes a ton of test failures.
Is this a hashing issue? Some playing with GDB suggests that the wrong
methods are being called, because potion_lookup is returning the wrong

Signed-off-by: why the lucky stiff <why@whytheluckystiff.net>
* Makefile: remove JIT_DEBUG. it's not a common setting and bsd make has a different if syntax. it can just go in CFLAGS.

* core/string.c: well, had to sort out the hash tables again. i made a mess of the string table. since the string wasn't kept as the key, collisions weren't cared for. i'm now keeping the string's khash id in its struct, for use in the method lookup table. come to think of it, i'm assuming that id never changes. time to read up.
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:why/potion

make 'make DEBUG=1 test' work

Dumping out JIT code when DEBUG=1 makes that 'make test' fails. This
patch instead dumps when make is passed JIT_DEBUG.

* core/vm.c: trigger jit dumping via JIT_DEBUG instead of DEBUG flag
* Makefile: add JIT_DEBUG

Signed-off-by: why the lucky stiff <why@whytheluckystiff.net>
* core/objmodel.c: experimenting with 32-bit support in the compiled method cache.

* core/objmodel.c: having a go at a compiled method lookup table. this is very rudimentary, but i'm hoping it'll eventually become O(n log n), along with some nice code to find the intersection between two sets of mixins. my entire method lookup strategy is based on this compiled method cache and the JIT_ICACHE. i am considering some different strategies for the compiled cache, such as making it global, keying off of a hash of (mixin, method) or keying off of name first. it also might be quicker to give certain mixin combinations their own type id.
 * core/vm.c: bug in 64-bit JIT_ICACHE. the initial mov 0x1 uses %eax, no prefix needed. (both JIT_MCACHE and JIT_ICACHE will be enable once i have cache expiry in place and 32-bit is solid.)

* core: straightening out the hashtables. the plain PNTable indexes (PN, PN) pairs, while the string and method tables index (uint32, PN). and the uint32 hash is kept in the PNString struct. also switched to the khash built-in string hashing method, since it doesn't rely on strlen and, generally, strings are going to be short while byte arrays will be longer.
* core/compile.c: call OP_SELF before running an anonymous closure, since they run in the parent's scope.
* core/vm.c: fixes to upvals. two problems. first, loading the closure was overwriting self in register 0. second, all the upval operations were off, with respect to PNWeakRef struct.
Merge branch 'master' of orleans.hobix.com:~/git/potion
* core/pn-gram.y: a more flexible unary minus. decrement operators were wrong.
* README: inspect is no longer with us.

* core/objmodel.c: adding mixin names to the lobby. a bug in the automatic getter routine of potion_def_method.
 * core/internal.c: extra lobby type created.

* core/compile.c: send an OP_SELF instruction before any expression which begins with a method call. this changes the behavior of message passing in test/flows/if.pn, but i'd prefer to simplify the parser and compiler.
 * core/vm.c: the simplest of OP_SELF.
 * core/objmodel.c: introspective `kind` and `self` methods.
* core/vm.c: first register should be nil, locals can be uninitialized.

* core/potion.h: get rid of some complexity by moving all primitives into the lower three bits. weak refs still have a flag on the third bit, for use in upvals. a1k0n spotted a problem with potion_release's expectation of 16-byte alignments. but we really only expect 8-byte alignments. also got rid of PN_REF_FLAG and PN_NUM_FLAG macros since the type values themselves can be used.
* core/potion.c: allocate extra byte for the closing '\0'. was crashing on windows and rightfully so.
* Makefile: split version.h into version.h (included in tarball) and config.h (generated by make).
* Makefile: i suppose i need both c-compiling syntaxes to support gnu and bsd make alike?
* Makefile: based on lutzky's patch to get make -j working, but works with bsd make as well.

* core/compile.c: do the conditional check one register up, to allow messages to be passed to whatever's in the main register. (for example: `x if 1: clone. else: string.` will send `x clone`.)
 * core/table.c: list() method in the lobby for pre-allocating a list.
 * core/vm.c: place nil in bytecode's VM register 0, like the JIT does.
 * core/objmodel.c: simple inheritance, this is only here to get the lobby working, it'll change soon enough.
* core/vm.c: correcting the jit's icache jmp on 64-bit.
* core/vm.c: experimenting with the jit's inline method cache (off by default.) modifying the code in place rather than allocating static variable space.
Merge branch 'master' of why@orleans.hobix.com:~/git/potion
* core/compile.c: bug discovered by quag in test/flow/continue.pn. turned out i hadn't expanded the register count when compiling the inc/dec operators.

micro optimization: use lea instruction rather than add/or

changed compiler macro so gcc generates the lea instruction, and shaved
a byte (or two for x86-64) off each X86_MATH().  this used to be faster,
but i have no idea whether it makes a difference to a modern processor.

specifically, converting to a tagged integer (PN_NUM(i) and X86_MATH)
generates lea eax, [1+eax+eax*1] (opcode 8d 44 00 01) instead of add
eax, eax/or eax, 1 (01 c0 83 c8 01).

Ensure 16-byte alignment on the stack

This is why stuff is breaking on OS X: it uses movdqa which will fail
because potion is offsetting the stack by 4, 8, or 12 bytes.

All JIT tests pass on OS X 32-bit.  64-bit untested.
Merge branch 'master' of why@orleans.hobix.com:~/git/potion
* Makefile: delete compiled tests.
* core/potion.c: test/string/shift.pn was crashing on bsd, due to no closing zero.
* Makefile: tarball task.
* core/compile.c: dump decimal/bignums in bytecode. fixes some compiler tests.
* core/compile.c: fix storage of empty strings.
* Makefile: add tests of round-tripping bytecode.
* core: rebelling against matz.

* core/table.c: basic table support, auto-conversion from tuple to table. one thing i like about the tables syntax is that it prevents people from using assignment in conditionals. `if (a=1)` can return a syntax error because the compiler will detect this as a table rather than an assignment. `(a==1)` is a tuple of `(true)`, whereas `(a=1)` is a table of {"a": 1}. the other thing i like is that list/tables are interchangeable as named parameters, meaning every function has named parameters really.
 * core/vm.c: the OP_SETTABLE instruction. the value is kept in reg + 1, implicitly.
* test: string <-> number casting tests.
* core: change `inspect` to `string`. add `number` cast for strings.
* core/potion.c: merged quag's updated printf fix.

* core/number.c: starting bignum/float representation. a note about this. a lot of languages use this style of storing bignums. ruby, python, libtommath, etc. the trick to fast bignum operations isn't the math, in my opinion. it's memory allocation. if you're doing an iterative fibonacci, for instance, you could end up with millions of allocations between the math operations. so, i want to optimize this in the vm by offering bignum registers that are reused. in the case of the fib, we'd have five registers and no other allocations. assignments would simply overwrite those registers.
* core/potion.c: it looks like the __APPLE__ def indicates any flavor of darwin. i guess we'll see.

* core/potion.c: going with quag's printf hack on osx. it appears that osx does some trick to initialize stdout. probably to accomodate stdout piped to Console.app in GUI apps. anyway, the JIT messes with this. my guess is that inside printf it's trying to trace back through the call stack to find out if you're in a GUI app or not. and it can't trace back through potion's function pointers. however, fflush(stdout) doesn't seem to fix the problem.
* core/compile.c: translated the locals dump wrong a few commits ago.
* core/string.c: okay, pn_printf args working. varargs. it's been awhile.

* core/string.c: adding reallocation of size to the byte buffer. pn_printf for formatting c strings and appending them.
 * core: on all objects, inspect now returns a string representation. i still need to fix some printf calls in potion_source_compile.
Adding test for packing numbers in bytecode
Align comments in bytecode listing (-V)
Updating string slice(n, n) signature

* core: multiple args in the bytecode VM. the compiler flattens all argument lists into a series of getlocal/getupval calls, to avoid creating tuples all over the place. with optional or omitted arguments, i'll need to pass in a tuple, however. the idea here is to make sure that we still give every potion closure a concrete c function signature.

* core/vm.c: fantastic. discovered the big problem on x86-64. the stack pointer wasn't being shifted enough. (incidentally, i did some research on callee-saved registers and the only one i need to be careful of is %rbx. i'm not using it anymore, but i think i was using it to lookup pointers previously.) http://www.sun.com/bigadmin/features/articles/amd64_debugging.jsp
* core/compile.c: get rid of OP_MASK, it doesn't work for numbers, as quag points out. just store in PN_OP->a and compare.
* core/opcodes.h: use a mask for the OP_LOADPN check, to cut down the macros.
Merge commit 'quag/master'

* core/vm.c: an experimental inline method cache for the jit. this is turned off by default until it proves to be really worth it. i allocate some bytes at the end of the assembled x86 instructions (4 * sizeof(PN) for each method lookup found) and use it to cache a closure. in theory, this is a great way to speed things up because the jumps are small and you're likely to have the same (mixin, method) query happen over and over again at these calls. also the cache is kept with the machine code buffer, so they get released by gc simultaneously. it may not save a whole lot of speed in the end, though, since potion strings are immutable and can be pre-hashed, so lookups are pretty good.

Annotate '-V' byte code listings

For example:

  [12] setlocal 0 2   ; c
  [13] getlocal 0 2   ; c
  [14] notjmp 0 3     ; to 18
  [15] loadpn 0 14    ; false
  [16] setlocal 0 2   ; c
  [17] jump -5	      ; to 13
  [18] loadpn 0 1     ; 0
  [19] setlocal 0 5   ; i
  [20] getlocal 0 5   ; i
  [21] loadpn 1 3     ; 1
  [22] add 0 1
  [23] setlocal 0 5   ; i
Pack small numbers into loadpn instead of loadk

* core: c closures and potion closures are now stored identically, with the function pointer in ->method and upvals in ->data. method dispatch is working. also got bit shifting operators going.
* core: div, rem, pow, settable ops in the jit.
* core: added `elsif`.
* core: 32-bit calling ops were all wrong.
* core: yay! nailed c calling convention, which means i can send arguments to c and potion funcs both the same.
* core: messing with c calling convention.
* core: different argument passing strategy on 32-bit jit.
* core: for now, always adjust the stack pointer, until i can detect recursion.
* core: upvals are starting to work in the jit!
* core: wrap jit functions in a closure for passing upvals.
* core/potion.h: optimize the type checking macros.
* core: switched to using weakrefs and an upval pointer list for the bytecode vm. slowed things down a bit, but will be much better for the jit.
* core: rework passing of arguments in both the bytecode and jit.
* core: move the stack pointer, if we have many registers/locals.
* core: bug in jit'd setlocal.
* Makefile: attempting to coalesce the mingw stuff with bsd make.
* Makefile: mingw.o not mingw.c.
* core: getting jit codes in play on mingw.
* Makefile: turn ssp back on now that mmap function pointers are working.
* core: bug in X86_CALL on 64-bit.
* core: working on nested jit protos, operator support in the parser, fixed OP_MULT.
* core: jit for locals, move, bug in RBP().
* core: jit code casts to 32-bit for math.
* core: lovely idea from a very, very simple jit that builds an x86 function pointer.
* core: trying to optimize tuple and math operations.
* core: cutting down on amount of table allocations for the moment. upvals are pointers now.
* core: some basic if/else, no automatic returns on blocks and jmp fixes.
* core: many upvals are now working, passing closures around.
* core: splat the if args.
* core: working on optimized if/else calls.
* core: the vm is no longer recursive, but forced tail recursive like the lua vm.
* core: working on cmp, bitl, bitr, neq, eq opcodes.
* core: align PN_OP struct to four bytes for three arguments, the first being a 6-bit opcode.
* core: okay, moved over to PN_OP struct.
* core: more opcodes, more compilation. i'm erring on the side of more opcodes, since i don't want third parameters like lua.
* core: get function signatures to bind the appropriate local vars.
* core/compile.c: compile the function signatures.
* Makefile: return 0 so rm -f can happen.
* Makefile: get `make version` to work on cygwin/mingw.
* Makefile: a few more sizeofs and endianness defs.
* Makefile: sneaky ways of getting the makefile to work on bsd.

* Makefile: uint and ulong sizes. a gcc one-liner!
 * core/compile.c: redundant macros.
* core: function signature parser, for use in the c api.
* core: compilation under mingw. use calloc to clear khash mem.
* core/compile.c: counting stacks, working on path calls.
* core: basic dumping and loading of bytecode is happenin.

* test: added some testing of type-related macros and method calls.
 * core/potion.h: bug in potion_is_ref.
* core: starting the dumping and loading of bytecode.
* Makefile: build core/version.h before building everything else.
* core/potion.h: the vtable TODO is cared for.
* core: allow closures stored in locals to be executed with `name()`.
* core: nested blocks. no scope or anything yet. but ran a closure, not bad.
* core: introduced the vm exec loop. ran my first program!
* README: outlining the object model.
* core: figured out my register strategy. parsing of blocks, protos, methods now working closer to what i like.
* core: adding more opcodes, working on more compile steps, fixing grammar issues.
* core: continuing work on the compiler, inspection of byte code.

* core/string.c: bug in string table was causing duplicate strings. i didn't know it but khash needs to keep a pointer to the string key, for comparison later. that's fine, but i need to give it the pointer to the single PN allocated when the key is inserted. strings sent through potion_str2 screwed things up because they are altered after insertion.
 * core/potion.h: structure for keeping compiled bytecode.
* core/pn-scan.rl: playing with the modulo operator.
* core/potion.h: discovered allocation problem, casting to PN_NUM and back wasn't happening in PN_OBJ_ALLOC.
* core: add inspect to primitives.
* example/fib.pn: the fibonacci example.
* core: byte streams and starting work on the compiler.
* Makefile: don't count `tools` in the sloc count.
* core: asts for the data nodes.

* core: store root ast in P->source. count bad allocations.

* core: solve warnings. i guess %zd is the printf format for size_t.
* core: parser now producing an ast.
* core: started adding the ast type and hooking the parser in.
* core: cleaning up style.
* core: switch vtables to khashes.
* core: introduce khash for tablekeeping. move the string table over to khash.
Merge branch 'master' of why@orleans.hobix.com:~/git/potion
* core: new potion_method macro for adding method signatures.
* core/potion.c: make the version note a valid data atom.
* Makefile: sloc make tasks, to roughly count the lines of code in the distro.
* core: add a string method, remove the --test option, solve warnings.
* core: add number methods, get strings table happening.
* core: wrapped up a basic object model, based on id, but i don't allocate a vtable for every object. a vtable is defined only when a method is defined.
* core/potion.h: importing table/array type from lua.
* Makefile: in todo task, show line number and trim the sentence.

* core/string.c: basic string allocation and hashing, borrowed from lua.

* core/potion.h: starting work on strings and vtables.

* core/potion.c: on the fibonacci, do a type check.

* README: describtion.

* core/objmodel.c: sketching out the basic object model, inspired by ian piumarta's extensible id model.

* core/potion.h: PNGarbage, the gc header for each object.
* core: detailing the primitive types in core/potion.h. using a ruby VALUE-like structure to decrease memory use and increase math speeds. the price is paid in PN_TYPE, but it's very minor.

* Makefile: adding -Wall.

* core: okay, first checkin. the parser is coming together. started this on the 15th.

Honor completion-ignored-extensions

The built-in generic and generic-git projects were generating completion
lists including all sorts of bogus file names.  Some examples include:

  foo.el~
  foo.elc

These files are normally ignored by Emacs' filename completion.

This patch modifies eproject-find-file to honor Emacs'
completion-ignored-extensions list.  This cleans up the completion list,
removing editor backup files, byte-compiled Lisp files, and other file
types specified by the user.

Signed-off-by: Jonathan Rockway <jrockway@cpan.org>

issue.title: Created README from Melpa description
issue.body: Added a readme with Github formatting based Melpa description

issue.title: eproject.el: don't barf on non file backed buffers
issue.body:
While eproject-maybe-turn-on is only called on various mode hooks it
breaks on temporary buffers if they use a programming mode. One such
example is when exporting an org-mode document with embedded source
code.

This stops it throwing an error by skipping the attempt if there is no
associated (buffer-file-name) for the buffer.

issue.title: eproject-maybe-turn-on gets run 3 times every time file is opened
issue.body:
eproject-maybe-turn-on and thus also <project-name>-project-file-visit-hook gets run 3 times every time a file in a project is opened or a buffer in a project is reverted.
- Once due to after-change-major-mode-hook being run when changing to fundamental-mode
- Once due to after-change-major-mode-hook being run when changing to whatever major-mode is appropriate for the buffer (erlang-mode in my case)
- Once due to the file-visit-hook.

It's may be a little difficult to get away from the change-major-mode duplicate call since the convention is to kill all local variables as part of the major-mode setup, but since after-change-minor-mode-hook will be run on file-visit/buffer-revert anyway, maybe you could just remove the file-visit-hook?

issue.title: Add ability to have a func return a compile string
issue.body:
Sometimes you want something fancier that a simple string for your make
invocations. This way you can define a function in your :common-compiles
list which can return a string or nil. The function is passed the
eproject-root. Any nils are removed from the final list passed back to
the compile history.

issue.title: "Argument list too long" -> introduced contrib/eproject-find-cmd.el
issue.body:
I'm running into command line length limitations for large projects (many files found by :relevant-files).  Seems that functions like eproject-list-project-files\* can generate very long strings, and try to pass them to the shell (e.g. grep via eproject-grep).

I haven't seen any previous issues about this -- have any others seen and/or worked around this limit?

As an alternative for consideration (maybe there's a better solution?), I started implementing some eproject definitions with the find-cmd package, and creating "find | xargs" based extras. e.g. "relevant files" defined with (and (type "f") (or (name "_.h") (name "_.c")))).

issue.title: Add the option to shortcut eproject file searching if project already open.
issue.body:
I present this for discussion rather than actual merge material. I'm
sure there are cleaner ways to achieve what we want. However for the
time being this ameliorates the rather crippling performance I was
seeing over TRAMP.

issue.title: Let projects control arguments passed to the eproject-tags-etags command
issue.body:
This commit allows the following:

```
(define-project-type foo (generic)
  (look-for "foo.cfg")
  :tags-cmd-args (lambda (root) '("-R" "--languages=-JavaScript" "my/files")))
```

which - when eproject-tags is called from a foo project - will invoke etags with:

```
etags -o .TAGS-tmp --verbose -R --languages=-JavaScript my/files
```

issue.title: IDO issue
issue.body:
I'm trying to use eproject with it set to use ido-completing-read.  It appears that it eventually winds up trying to string-match on some sort of buffer reference(I know next to nothing about lisp).  Any ideas.  I've pasted the last couple of lines of the backtrace.

(wrong-type-argument stringp #<buffer Blah.scala>)
  string-match("" #<buffer Blah.scala>) ...some junk here
ido-set-matches-1((#<buffer Blah.scala> #<buffer Blah2.scala>) t)

issue.title: Magit support
issue.body: Implementation credit goes to @binarin, but I'm requesting a merge because I find it useful. Admittedly, special-casing magit-status-mode buffers smells a little wrong, but the same thing is done with dired buffers. Ideally, there'd be some macro that provides a generic way to add special case buffers to the tests in  `eproject--buffer-file-name`, but I haven't spent any time on it because this works for me.

issue.title: generate ibuffer filter groups from eproject info
Why add hook to after-change-major-mode-hook
issue.body:
Hi!

I was wondering if there's a particular reason to add the hook to after-change-major-mode-hook? Right now this has the effect that whenever I open a project source-file, my <project>-project-file-visit-hook gets run 3 times. Once for find-file-hook and twice for the after-change-major-mode-hook.

I think it seems enough to just keep the find-file-hook. Am I missing something?

issue.title: Add option to prefer outermost project
issue.body:
For some configurations it makes more sense to relate opened files to the topmost project type.

In my case I rarely (if ever) change anything in a subproject without considering it to be part of its superproject and then it can become cumbersome to have all files in my subprojects (generally git submodules or Erlang rebar dependencies) as parts of separate projects.

This is also a better way to solve the issues I tried to solve with https://github.com/jrockway/eproject/pull/43 so I'll close that.

issue.title: Introduce project facets (parallel project types)
issue.body:
This is a feature suggestion.

Currently eproject does hierarchical inheritence of project types with the exception that it does not allow to extend an  project-type property but only replace it.

It would be great if multiple project types could be used at once.

An simple example would be an Django application which depends on coffee-script probably could benifit from being both project types at once.
At the moment I am merging most of my "web"-framework project types by hand and would probably use more project types and things like the recently added tasks if it were easier to mix and match.

Draft of simple functional requirements:
- Support for facets/parallel project types, possibly if they are identified at the same directory level.
- A project definition can be a main project type, project facet or both.
- There should be some control mechanism for which project facets an main project type can use.
- Easy toggling of facets/project types, possibly using the minibuffer/ido or similar.
- (maybe) a possibility to define which project facets that cannot be used at the same time.

issue.title: Consider the outermost currently open project as the project root
issue.body:
This is a feature suggestion.

Simple specs:
- Must be optional
- Be turned off by default
- Have custotimzeable default 
- Have an interactive toggle-function

issue.title: Optimize looking for the project root
issue.body:
When working locally, the process is fast enough, but when using Tramp (over plink), eproject is one of the primary slowdown factors for me.

These changes cut down file opening time from 4-4.5 seconds to 1-1.5, for example, in one "best case" scenario. They don't do much for out-of-project files, though.

issue.title: eproject does not play well with desktop
issue.body:
The way the eproject minor mode is defined causes a problem with Emacs' desktop library.

When reloading a saved desktop, 'desktop-create-buffer' is called for each buffer that is to be recreated. Desktop remembers the name of each active minor mode from when the desktop was saved, and if that name is fbound, desktop-create-buffer calls that function in order to activate the minor mode for the buffer.

Unfortunately 'eproject-mode' is defined to raise an error when called in a new buffer (where eproject-root is null). This error brings desktop loading to a crashing halt.

Is there a good reason that eproject-mode cannot just call eproject-maybe-turn-on itself, when eproject-root is null?

EDIT: looking into it further, you should be able to fix this easily by adding eproject-mode to the variable 'desktop-minor-mode-table'.

issue.body: I think they should. Otherwise it's too much tweaking...

issue.title: Simple way to require extras
issue.body: We need a simple way to require extras. Probably eproject/extras should be added to load-path when eproject-extras required?

issue.title: Hang when selecting files outside eproject directory
issue.body:
I get a hang when I try and open files outside any existing eproject definitions. Typically this usually manifests when opening stuff via tramp but can be on local NFS systems. I can break out of the hang with Ctrl-G and the buffer is loaded but without any font locking on.

Using edebug I got to the this backtrace:

  run-hooks(after-change-major-mode-hook)
  run-mode-hooks(text-mode-hook)
  text-mode()
  normal-mode(t)
  after-find-file(nil t)
  find-file-noselect-1(#<buffer rnotes.tex<####>> "/eng/ajb/####/#####/doc/rnotes.tex" nil nil "/eng/ajb/#####/####/doc/rnotes.tex" (48634650 25))
  find-file-noselect("/eng/ajb/########/#####/doc/rnotes.tex" nil nil nil)
  find-file("/eng/ajb/######/#####/doc/rnotes.tex")
  my-test()

Looking at after-change-major-mode-hook

(eproject--after-change-major-mode-hook global-font-lock-mode-enable-in-buffers)

I concluded eproject has gone off on a wild one somewhere. I see the maybe-turn-on logic has been refactored. Should I be tracking the virtual projects branch now?

issue.title: Problem with non-file buffers
issue.body:
There is a bug in eproject--selector. It assumes that every buffer where 'eproject-maybe-turn-on' is invoked, must be a file. I am using SLIME (emacs mode for common lisp programming). I have defined a "common-lisp project" like this:

(define-project-type common-lisp (generic) (look-for "*.asd" :glob)
  :relevant-files '("\.lisp$" "\.lsp$" "\.asd$"))
(add-hook 'lisp-mode-hook 'eproject-maybe-turn-on)

Slime creates non-file buffers that are still 'lisp mode', such as _SLIME Macroexpansion_. Eproject prevents interactive macroexpansion because of the error raised when it finds the new buffer is not a file.

I think it should just do nothing silently when it tries to 'turn on' and finds the buffer is not a file.

issue.title: Option to parse brackets into lists
issue.body:
For example, this:

``` clojure
(foo [1, 2, 3])
```

should parse to _something_, maybe `[*foo, [*vec 1, 2, 3]]` or  `[*foo, \[1, 2, 3]]`, but not a Parse error.

issue.title: Option to parse braces into hashes
issue.body:
For example,

``` clojure
{"ace" 1, "deuce" 2, "trey" 3}
```

would parse to

``` perl
{"ace" => 1, "deuce" => 2, "trey" => 3}
```

Of course the degenerate case would simply be a set:

``` clojure
{"ace", "deuce", "trey"}
```

``` perl
{"ace" => '', "deuce" => '', "trey" => ''}
```

zsh.vim

Fix the bug that if there is a ' sign in a comment, highlight will break
when that line is absent on the screen.

After some `hard` debuging, I found that it is the 'display' option
that should be blamed. According to the help, 'If the "display" argument
is given,  this item will be skipped when the detected highlighting will
not be displayed.'. So if the line is absent on current screen, it won't
be parsed at all... That means the ' sign in the line will trigger the
zshString syntax. You will got the whole file highlighted as strings
until an other ' sign appears...

mv shell related stuff to shells/ and add shells/profile

Bash won't source ~/.profile of it found ~/.bash_profile. Zsh won't
source it either when ~/.zprofile was found. But they all source it
instead of their own startup files when invoked as sh. So I want to put
the common stuff their and let .bash_profile and .zprofile source it
manually.

let the profiles of zsh and bash export GTK_IM_MODULE etc. too

Ok, I admit that these things are only GUI related but one would always
start GUI program from a terminal. If we don't export them in the
profiles of zsh, bash and etc., they will be overwritten by system
settings.

But this commit violate the Do-Not-Repeat-Yourself principle. I may
perfect that peace later.

Fix test 23 in t/application/cache.t.

$mech->delete_header( 'Accept-Encoding' ) isn't enough. WWW::Mechanize will
add Accept-Encoding: gzip automatically if Compress::Zlib is available.
$mech->add_header( 'Accept-Encoding' => 'identity' ) is the right thing to
do.

t/application/cache.t: fix the same issue as in the previous commit.

To get the gziped response from WWW::Mechanize you need to call
$mech->response->content.

Fix test 19 in t/application/cache.t.

WWW::Mechanize automatically uncompresses gzip responses. Therefor trying
to get the gziped content via $mech->content is wrong. The raw response
body may be accessed via $mech->response->content.

Fix test 5 in t/application/cache.t.

WWW::Mechanize automatically adds an Accept-Encoding: gzip header if
Compress::Zlib is available. Explicitly setting Accept-Encoding to not
include gzip fixes that.

For some reason, the blank line threw off the length calculation
algorithm, resulting in indentations like:

  foo   => 'bar',
  bar   => 'baz',

instead of the expected:

  foo => 'bar',
  bar => 'baz',

I don't know if this is the real cause or not; but it seemed to fix

issue.title: Uses espresso-mode instead of the patched js2-mode
issue.body:
Hi Jon,

I no longer use your elisp repo (I've been building my own), and I discovered a patched js2-mode that fixes the crappy indentation and I thought you might be interested

Here's a commit in my own repo that pulls it in as a submodule and performs customisation only to enable pretty lineup of multiline var declarations

https://github.com/jjl/elisp/commit/ad1453b196e3727bfb9379a7d3624a702606ad50

Or alternatively you may be interested in this page which describes how to use js2-mode with espresso's indentation (plus he hacked in a couple of extras including the multiline var thing).

http://mihai.bazon.net/projects/editing-javascript-with-emacs-js2-mode

/j

Following a private security bug report from megablue I went through all 
command.cpp sprintf function calls and added limits to the string 
formatting and also ran the file through a sed filter to replace all 
"std::sprintf(msgtemp," with "snprintf(msgtemp, sizeof(msgtemp), " (and 
the same for msgtemp2). This hopefully will close all buffer overflow 
bugs lurking in there (besides the ones reported by megablue I also 
found some potentially exploitable locations).

git-svn-id: svn://svn.berlios.de/pvpgn/trunk@361 f47984b3-f1e4-0310-9569-ebefd53020b6

On MinGW when one uses "-ansi" (or "-std=c++98) the gcc defined 
__STRICT_ANSI__ define is used to not declare most of it's POSIX system 
emulation API but declare only ISO library functions. This is of course 
completely braindead as -ansi is used to tell the compiler to make sure 
the code is standard compliant not that the code uses ONLY standard 
library features (the 2 notions are not the same thing). So disable 
strict ANSI mode for MINGW.

git-svn-id: svn://svn.berlios.de/pvpgn/trunk@344 f47984b3-f1e4-0310-9569-ebefd53020b6

Unified autotools/cmake config file generation. Basically modified the 
file.conf.in use ${LOCALSTATEDIR}/${SYSCONFDIR} instead of 
"/usr/local/etc" and "/usr/local/var" and have them replaced with the 
paths according to the configured installation prefix. What is very nice 
now is that theoretically on windows when using cmake we wouldnt need 
anymore the file.conf.win32 versions as cmake can generate proper 
versions for win32 from the .in version as it does on POSIX systems (if 
you worry about "/" being used as file system separation character 
instead of "\" you should know that Windows does support "/" separation 
just fine in it's C/C++ APIs so it should work).

git-svn-id: svn://svn.berlios.de/pvpgn/trunk@171 f47984b3-f1e4-0310-9569-ebefd53020b6

Double the size of gamename/gamepass (really was a problem for users 
typing non-ASCII chars in UTF-8 where it eats more than one byte for a 
char). When I unified the macros for d2cs/d2dbs and bnetd, d2cs/d2dbs 
had these small values for gamename/gamepass and bnetd had the 32 bytes 
values. I decided that smaller is safer. However, let's increase it now 
and see if it breaks anything on d2cs/d2dbs part, it shouldnt as I dont 
really think Blizzard implemented different limits for gamename/gamepass 
on D2 clients than all the other clients, whould be really stupid.

git-svn-id: svn://svn.berlios.de/pvpgn/trunk@165 f47984b3-f1e4-0310-9569-ebefd53020b6

Added preliminary support to cross-compile pvpgn for win32 with mingw32 
on a POSIX box (ie requiring a shell and such) by usage of the standard 
autogen/configure/make method. To use it do something like:
./configure --host=i386-mingw32msvc 
--with-includes=/path/to/xmingw-runtime/include 
--with-libraries=/path/to/xmingw-runtime/lib
Where "/path/to/xmingw-runtime" is some directory where you install a 
cross-compiled win32 libz.a (I done one myself from the sources of 
zlib) because pvpgn requires it. Your PATH must point to a directory 
where "i386-mingw32msvc-g++" and such are found and also the cross 
compiler will need to automatically have its own include/lib directories 
with things like "winsock2.h" and "libws2_32.a" (winsock32 lib).

name: midiator
description: A Ruby library for interacting with system MIDI services.

commit.message: Fixed tyop in midi#play. Added drum_chords.rb to show MIDIator::Drums usage
Made chords.rb OS generic (was Mac dls_synth specific)
Interface#play can now play chords; added chords.rb demo to examples
add Jeremy to the README
method name rejigger
add Jeremy's cc, aftertouch, and pitch bend code.  yay!
whitespace
everything in its place
add Adam Murray to the README
add spec for DLSSynth require
clean up DLS synth a little
Added Adam Murray's DLSSynth driver.
Implemented control changes.
Changed CoreMIDI client name to MIDIator.
note_off's velocity defaults to 0.
update examples to include instruct_user!
add Driver#instruct_user! method; make the linux driver pause for hooking up alsa stuff
reformat README a little, add email for Giles
add url for xavier
i can has word wrap
add contributor notices, move some requires around, add Platform dependency, 0.2.0!
Changed the platform detection to use the Platform gem instead of RUBY_PLATFORM - better edge case detection, esp. for Windows - and silenced warnings during the constant reassignment section.
Remove invalid MIDI notes, they clash with the NOTE_OFF event and we don't want to encourage any one to even try and use them.
add rubygems to the examples
oops, broke the core_midi driver.  fix it and release 0.1.1
bump to version 0.1.0... release?
add a method to flush the workqueue and change is_a to kind_of to match the book
tweak some of the coremidi code to be more verbose/clear
fix whitespace.  this is actually a hook test, heh
add gem packaging tasks
ignore package directory
fix a warning
add platform autodetection
make sure the WinMM driver is required correctly
make sure the ALSA driver is required correctly
either I had the windows and alsa drivers mixed up or the book did.  either way, they were wrong and now hopefully they're right?
helps to actually require dl when you use it...

Revert "add a couple of specs to the interface spec".  This change was premature.

This reverts commit eea1f55d5bc2181e1da142d613514eed82bb8ed2.
whitespace cleanup!
rejigger the spec directory a bit
add a couple of specs to the interface spec
add method_missing to Interface so that you can directly pass messages on to the driver.  Also change metronome example to take advantage of this
update rdoc task to show all methods and use the hanna template
add a bunch of rdoc and fix up some formatting niggles
add the rdoc artifact to .gitignore
fix up the rdoc rake task
jeez! Fix copyrights. these belong to meeeeee
add signal handling and timer drift fix
add metronome example
add middle c shortcut
add timer module
reformat licenses
add a rest method to complement play
add rdoc tasks
add Topher to authors list
oops!  fix copyright.
Add the GM drums to their own shortcut module and add a divider in the requires in midiator.rb
Add #change_patch to MIDIator::Interface and change variable names in Driver to match.
Just a little comment fix.
whitespace
add notes that the drivers came from Practical Ruby Projects and are written/owned by Topher Cyll
take out some debugging
set chromatic scale example executable
add alsa and windows drivers straight from the book.  untested!
add Topher's license per the terms of the MIT license and a note in the README describing what's up with all that

Change to the MIT license to be fully license-compatible with the code taken from Practical Ruby Projects (which is released under the MIT license).  Note that the BSD and MIT licenses are effectively identical, so this license change does not alter your rights with respect to the code.
add simple example that can play a chromatic scale on OSX
add exceptions file and require it in midiator.rb
add note name shortcuts!
change signature of driver note_on/note_off methods; add play method to interface

Flesh out MIDIator::Driver.  Specifically:
 * add header comments
 * separate the various sections of the class definition with comments
 * add explanatory comments for self::inherited
 * add stubs methods for the Driver API
 * add the public methods that MIDIator::Interface interacts with
add CoreMIDI driver.  OSX works now!
exclude libraries and specs from coverage runs
add MIDIator::Interface and specs
remove requires from specs since that is handled in the spec helper
add driver_registry require to midiator.rb

change the way that we were modifying MIDIator::Driver's inherited behavior so that we can reset it after specs run.  This fixes a problem with other specs that access the same code getting the modified version instead of the original
add spec for MIDIator::Driver
add MIDIator, MIDIator::Driver, and MIDIator::DriverRegistry, along with the specs for DriverRegistry
add coverage artifact to gitignore
apparently the ident attributes A) don't do what I want and B) don't even work as advertised... so take them out

* Add Rakefile with testing infrasture
 * add String extensions and specs for same
update gitattributes
add .gitattributes
update LICENSE and README to match with the Rabal templates
* add README and LICENSE
use one compartment for compilation and evaluation
properly store filename
update example to use implicit request/response
update server to use handlers
make multiple declarations/lexicals work
add handler + static handler
add the compiler
for the time being, make the class mutable
use a class
oh, it works
initial import

name: rails
description: Ruby on Rails

commit.message: #1824: use duck typing to set day to 1
Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/rails/rails
Digest#validate_digest_response should accept request instead of controller

Added grouped_options_for_select helper method for wrapping option tags in optgroups. [#977 state:resolved]

Mysql#reconnect is set according to the 'reconnect' key in the connection spec.

The 'reconenct' boolean option is read from the connection specification
and is used to set the reconnect attribute of Mysql.  The default is
false in order not to change existing application behaviour.

Also, reconnect is set AFTER real_connect is called, so its value sticks
(the mysql gem sets reconnect to false inside real_connect).

Fix metal tests

Make generated Metal bits a pure rack endpoint application (not middleware)

Instead of calling super to pass the request on, return a 404.
The modified app looks like this:

  # app/metal/poller.rb
  class Poller
    def self.call(env)
      if env["PATH_INFO"] =~ /^\/poller/
        [200, {"Content-Type" => "text/html"}, "Hello, World!"]
      else
        [404, {"Content-Type" => "text/html"}, "Not Found"]
      end
    end
  end

But you aren't locked in to just Rails:

  # app/metal/api.rb
  require 'sinatra'
  Sinatra::Application.default_options.merge!(:run => false, :env => :production)
  Api = Sinatra.application unless defined? Api

  get '/interesting/new/ideas' do
    'Hello Sinatra!'
  end

Decorate responses from Rack Middleware and Rails Metal for the purposes of integration testing. A test for the following Metal:

    class Poller < Rails::Rack::Metal
      def call(env)
        if env["PATH_INFO"] =~ /^\/poller/
          [200, {"Content-Type" => "text/plain"}, "Hello World!"]
        else
          super
        end
      end
    end

might be tested like so:

  class PollerTest < ActionController::IntegrationTest
    test "poller returns hello world" do
      get "/poller"
      assert_response 200
      assert_response :success
      assert_response :ok
      assert_equal "Hello World!", response.body
    end
  end

Signed-off-by: Michael Koziarski <michael@koziarski.com>

Making the IP Spoofing check in AbstractRequest#remote_ip configurable.

Certain groups of web proxies do not set these values properly.  Notably,
proxies for cell phones, which often do not set the remote IP information
correctly (not surprisingly, since the clients do not have an IP address).

Allowing this to be configurable makes it possible for developers to choose
to ignore this simple spoofing check, when a significant amount of their
traffic would result in false positives anyway.

Add a MessageEncryptor, just like MessageVerifier but using symmetric key encryption.

The use of encryption prevents people from seeing any potentially secret values you've used.  It also supports and encrypt_and_sign model to prevent people from tampering with the bits and creating random junk that gets fed to

A motivated coder could use this to add an :encrypt=>true option to the cookie store.

Fixed RFC-2045 quoted-printable bug [#1421 state:committed]

http://www.faqs.org/rfcs/rfc2045.html says:

          may be
          represented by an "=" followed by a two digit
          hexadecimal representation of the octet's value.  The
          digits of the hexadecimal alphabet, for this purpose,
          are "0123456789ABCDEF".  Uppercase letters must be
          used; lowercase letters are not allowed.

ActionMailer, however, used "=%02x" specification.

Signed-off-by: Jeremy Kemper <jeremy@bitsweat.net>

Fix that HTML::Node.parse would blow up on unclosed CDATA sections.

If an unclosed CDATA section is encountered and parsing is strict, an
exception will be raised. Otherwise, we consider the remainder of the line to
be the section contents. This is consistent with HTML::Tokenizer#scan_tag.

* Rails::GemDependency was missing definitions for hash and eql?, causing Array#uniq to not work.

* If several versions of a gem are unpacked in vendor, now chooses the highest if no version is specified.

* streamlined add_load_path. Now sets up Rubygems correctly to allow 'gem' to find frozen gems, with
  gems frozen to vendor/gems and specifications in vendor/gems/<gem-name>/.specification

* Rails::GemDependency#specification would return a spec for the highest installed version, even for
  frozen gems and/or previously loaded lower versions. See in part ticket #1123.

* removed vendor from default_load_paths - it was causing autoloading to append Gems::Gems::<gem-dir> to
  constant names

* added additional tests for loading frozen gems.

* incorporates the fix from #1107 for vendor rails

* defers to freeze:gems for handling the Rails framework. gems:unpack WILL NOT place a copy of Rails
  in vendor/gems. Should close #1123 completely.

* incorporates, via using the gem loader for frozen gems, fixes corresponding to #227, #324, #362, #527, and #742.

* gem plugins now work the same whether frozen or not. Correctness of the behavior is a matter for another ticket...

The test runner now returns an exit code.

passed to its functions.

Replaced 
 with 
 in all source files as the cc compiler on Solaris
2.6 was unable to process the #define because of the 
. This might be
a problem with the preprocessor on that machine. Microsoft's cl.exe seems
to work just fine with 
 (i.e. no 
). So the code should keep working
for existing systems.

Checking in reviewed changes by Dave Glowacki <dglo@hyde.ssec.wisc.edu> who
has added (1) file name and line numbers to the error messages, (2)
AssertDblEquals for doubles, (3) Assert<X>Equals_Msg version of all the
Assert<X>Equals to pass in optional message which is printed out on assert
failure.

make-tests.sh now accepts arguments on command line. The arguments must be
.c files. If no arguments are are given it reads tests from all .c files in
the current directory. If arguments are given it uses only the files given
to generate the test suite.

Extended JSON support, merge_hashes support

 * Allow any parameter to be a JSON structure (formerly only
   MVC__Foo_bar) could be JSON.

 * Allow top-level MVC__Foo params

 * Use $c->config() instead of $c->config->{} to change the config,
   that way we get merge_hashes for free

bump version

Support complex environment variable values via JSON/YAML

It is not possible to pass in values such as DSN connection
parameters, as these must be specified as a non-scalar.  If the
value in the variable looks like it might be JSON (ie, starts with
a '[' or '{', then parse it as JSON, using JSON.pm or YAML.pm

Support '__' as an alternative to '::' in environment variable names

Colons are not Bourne-shell compatible; double underscore seems like a
good alternative.  Also, avoid asking the user to install non-free
software in the documentation.

commit.message: Added a blueprint_attributes method useful for controller tests/specs
Vastly simplified internals of Sham.define (slaps forehead)
Gem version 0.1.7
Cleaned up Ian White's Sham.define patch.
Use the metaclass on a vanilla object rather than an anonymous class for Shame.define

make now supports overriding protected attributes.

(This used to work, but got broken in a code cleanup. There's now a spec.)

Gem version is now 0.1.6.
Updated the list of contributors in the README.
Update gem version to 0.1.5.
Allow id and type attributes in blueprints. (Thanks to Jon Guymon and Roland Swingler for pointing out the need for this, and providing equivalent patches.)
Added a "Gotchas" section to the readme highlighting possible problem attributes in blueprints and how to work around them.

Rewrote the specs.

I was using the same couple of blueprints for all the specs, and they were starting to smell a lot like fixtures. That was somewhere between ironic and hypocritical, so now each spec defines its own blueprint.

Cleaned up perryn's patch to allow strings as keys to make, which helps machinist play nicely with Cucumber's FIT tables.

Gem version is now 0.1.4.
Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/perryn/machinist into perryn
Added specs for accessing the object under construction and its attributes from within a blueprint.
allow string keys in parameters
allow strings as keys
Rolled the gem version up to 0.1.3.
Simplified Lathe#initialize after Clinton's changes.
Initialize attributes using 'new' rather than loop of assignments.
Took the glob out of the gemspec, so github doesn't complain when building the gem.
Ditched all the echoe gem stuff, and hand-rolled a gemspec. Much less confusing.
Updated version number to make github rebuild the gem.

Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/elight/machinist into elight/master

Brought in elight's fixes to make machinist work as a gem, and made them play nicely with my gemspec generation stuff.
Fixed a typo in the README. Thanks to Kyle Neath (http://github.com/kneath) for pointing it out.
Added the built gem to .gitignore.
Bumped to 1.0.1
Woops.  Specs break without checking if RAILS_ENV is defined.  Fixed
tweaking gemspec to attempt to induce github to build the gem
Now works as a gem and a plugin
Converted gem stuff to use echoee, and made it friendly with github's magic gem generation.
gemify
Moved the ActiveRecord extensions into their own model, to avoid polluting the ActiveRecord namespace any more than we need to.
Fixed up broken autotest depencies.
Added some credits to the README.
Fixed a minor error in the README.

Fixed bugs with blocks passed to make and make_unsaved.

Blocks passed to make now get called correctly, even inside a make_unsaved call.

Calls to make inside a block passed to make_unsaved will save the object.
Added make_unsaved method to allow constructing object graphs in memory.

Added a :unique option to Sham, to allow generating non-unique values.

This is based on code and discussion with Roland Swingler (http://github.com/knaveofdiamonds), so credit to him.
Rewrote Sham to be a bit neater, in preparation for adding some more options.
A few more clarifications.
A few more tweaks to the README.
Wrote a more comprehensive README.

You now how sometimes you write a couple of lines of code, and you're not happy with them, but you can't think of a nicer way, so you push them up to github, and only then do you work it out? Yeah, anyway.
make optionally takes a block, and passes in the created object. Suggested by technoweenie.

Make sure we don't reset the sequence returned by rand outside Sham.

Turns out Ruby's srand doesn't work the way you'd think. The seed value it returns is the initial value used to see the generator, not the current seed value. That means you can't use it to save and restore your spot in the sequence.
Added some rough docs for Sham, and got rid of the failed attempt to have Test::Unit automatically reset Sham before each test.
Simplified the Sham value generating code.
Made sure Sham couldn't get into an infinite loop generating values.
Added more Sham related things: resetting before each spec, index passed to sham blocks, autotest support.
Added first cut of Sham for generating repeatable random values for fields.
Got rid of the old README file. (Gotta remember that -a to git commit.)
Wrote some very basic docs.
More specs.
Added some basic specs.
Initial import.
bump version number

pass arguments to templates, put stash in $_

The attached patch changes the behavior of  
Catalyst::View::Template::Declare to pass arguments to the template  
functions, including the context, stash copy, and arguments passed to  
render().

Here's a new version that also sticks the stash copy in $_, for  
convenient access within the templates.

Don't remove is_auto_increment from source tables.

Mon Nov 10 01:33:31 2008: Request 40797 was acted upon.
Transaction: Ticket created by http://www.adamherzog.com/
       Queue: DBICx-MapMaker
     Subject: is_auto_increment being removed from source tables
   Broken in: 0.01
    Severity: Important
       Owner: Nobody
  Requestors: adam@adamherzog.com
      Status: new
 Ticket <URL: http://rt.cpan.org/Ticket/Display.html?id=40797 >

The is_auto_increment attributes are being removed from the primary
key columns in the left and right tables, as a side-effect of removing
them in order to create the map table.

I've attached a patch (including tests) which will remove the
is_auto_increment for the mapping table while leaving the left and
right tables unaffected.

issue.title: drop t/os/mac.t, per rt#83318
issue.body:
See https://rt.cpan.org/Public/Bug/Display.html?id=83318 for the full
discussion, but basically this test is failing everywhere that is Linux (at
least), and is not needed anymore as classic mac support has been dropped.
